Karl Marx (May 5, 1818 – March 14, 1883) was a German philosopher, economist, historian, sociologist, political theorist, journalist, and socialist revolutionary. Born in Trier, Prussia (now Germany), Marx's works became the foundation for modern socialism, communism, and anarchism.

Marx's work focused on the study of capitalism and the economic struggles between the working class (proletariat) and the wealthy (bourgeoisie). He believed that capitalism would inevitably collapse and be replaced by a socialist system, where the workers would own the means of production. This socialist system would eventually evolve into a classless, stateless communist society.

Marx's most significant work, Das Kapital (Capital: A Critique of Political Economy), was published posthumously in 1867, by Engels. In it, he critically analyzed the nature of capitalism and the exploitation of the working class.

Throughout his life, Marx's writings and theories inspired numerous social and political movements around the world. He is considered one of the most influential figures in human history and his ideas continue to shape the way we think about society, politics, and economics. Marx's legacy endures through the ongoing debates and discussions about socialism, communism, and capitalism.

Karl Marx passed away on March 14, 1883, in London, at the age of 64. Despite his efforts, Marx's theories were not immediately implemented, and many of his predictions and hopes did not materialize as he envisioned them. Nevertheless, Marx's ideas had a lasting influence on politics, economics, and social theory, inspiring revolutionary movements, political parties, and governments.

Marx spent the last years of his life editing "Das Kapital," and he died on March 14, 1883, in London. His ashes were later brought back to Germany, where they lie in the Zentralfriedhof in Berlin-Friedrichsfelde.

Karl Marx's legacy endures today, as his ideas continue to shape political debates, social movements, and academic disciplines. Despite the fact that his vision of communism did not become the dominant political system, Marx's work remains a cornerstone of modern socialist and political thought.

Karl Marx, born on May 5, 1818, in Trier, Germany, was a philosopher, economist, sociologist, and political theorist whose works profoundly influenced the trajectory of world history. His ideas became the foundation for the social science discipline known as Marxism.

Marx's early life was marked by economic hardship due to his father's early death and the onset of the German revolution of 1848. He began his academic journey in 1842 when he enrolled in the University of Bonn. However, due to his lack of funds, Marx initially attended university as a private pupil. He later transferred to the University of Berlin, where he studied philosophy, history, and law, and became a devout follower of Hegelian philosophy.

Marx's most significant academic achievements were made during his time in Paris. In 1844, he met Friedrich Engels, a young English industrialist, with whom he shared similar political views. This partnership led to their collaboration on the influential Communist Manifesto in 1848, which called for a working-class revolution against the capitalist ruling class.

After the publication of the Manifesto, Marx and Engels continued their partnership, producing several other works, such as the magnum opus "Das Kapital," a critique of the capitalist mode of production. They also co-founded the Communist League and advocated for the overthrow of the bourgeois state, which they believed would pave the way for a communist society.

Marx spent his last years in London, where he continued his work on economic and philosophical theories. Despite his significant contributions to world history, his ideas were often met with resistance and controversy. Marx's life was filled with hardship, including periods of poverty, imprisonment, and illness.

Karl Marx passed away on March 14, 1883, in London. Despite being a controversial figure throughout his life, Marx's theories continue to have a substantial impact on the social and political landscape of the modern world, influencing ideologies and movements ranging from socialism and communism to political science and philosophy. Karl Marx (May 5, 1818 – March 14, 1883) was a German philosopher, economist, sociologist, and political theorist, best known for his work in developing the body of theories that would later become known as Marxism. Born in Trier, Germany, he was raised in a liberal Jewish family and showed exceptional intellectual prowess from a young age.

Marx's most significant contributions to social science and political theory came through his critical analysis of capitalism and his prediction of a proletariat revolution, which he believed would ultimately lead to the establishment of a classless society. His works, mainly co-authored with Friedrich Engels, were first published in his seminal text, "The Communist Manifesto" (1848), followed by "Das Kapital" (1867) and other volumes detailing his theories.

Throughout his life, Marx was an active advocate of socialist ideals and participated in various political movements in Europe. He was a member of the Communist League, an association of German socialists, which he left due to disagreements over the methodology of achieving a proletarian revolution. In 1845, he married Jenny von Westphalen, a wealthy and progressive family's daughter.

In 1849, the Frankfurt Assembly nominated Marx as a representative of the working class in the short-lived German Empire. However, he had to flee to London, where he spent the rest of his life. In London, Marx continued his work as a political commentator, journalist, and writer, where he focused on critiquing capitalism, writing academic works, and establishing the International Workingmen's Association (First International).

Marx died on March 14, 1883, at the age of 64. His works continue to inspire political movements, socialists, and communists around the world, and he remains an influential figure in contemporary political and social thought.
